{{for|the German-American International Master|Edward Lasker}} {{good article}} {{Infobox chess player |name = Emanuel Lasker |image = Bundesarchiv Bild 102-00457, Emanuel Lasker.jpg |birthname = Emanuel Lasker |country = Germany |birth_date = December 24, 1868 |birth_place = Berlinchen, [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] (now [[Barlinek]], Poland) |death_date = January 11, 1941 (aged 72) |death_place = New York City, United States |worldchampion = 1894–1921 }}
'''Emanuel Lasker''' (December 24, 1868 – January 11, 1941) was a German [[chess]] player, [[mathematician]], and [[Philosophy|philosopher]] who was [[World Chess Championship|World Chess Champion]] for 27 years (from 1894 to 1921). In his prime, Lasker was one of the most dominant champions, and he is still generally regarded as one of the [[Comparison of top chess players throughout history|strongest players ever]].
His contemporaries used to say that Lasker used a "psychological" approach to the game, and even that he sometimes deliberately played inferior moves to confuse opponents. Recent analysis, however, indicates that he was ahead of his time and used a more flexible approach than his contemporaries, which mystified many of them. Lasker knew contemporary analyses of openings well but disagreed with many of them. He published chess magazines and five chess books, but later players and commentators found it difficult to draw lessons from his methods.
Lasker made contributions to the development of other games. He was a first-class [[contract bridge]] player<ref name="Laskeratbridge">A detailed examination of Emanuel Lasker’s involvement in bridge is provided by the chapter ''Nicht nur Schach Emanuel Lasker als Bridgespieler'' by Robert van de Velde on pages 332-363 of ''Emanuel Lasker Denker Weltenbürger Schachweltmeister'' edited by Richard Forster, Stefan Hansen and Michael Negele (Berlin, 2009).</ref> and wrote about bridge, [[Go (game)|Go]], and his own invention, [[Lasca]]. His books about games presented a problem that is still considered notable in the [[Mathematical game|mathematical analysis of card games]]. Lasker was also a research mathematician who was known for his contributions to [[commutative algebra]], which included proving the [[Lasker–Noether theorem|primary decomposition]] of the [[ideal of a ring|ideal]]s of [[polynomial ring]]s. His philosophical works and a [[drama]] that he co-wrote, however, received little attention.
== Life and career ==
=== Early years 1868–1894 === [[Image:Lasker.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Lasker as a young man]] Emanuel Lasker was born on December 24, 1868 at [[Berlinchen]] in [[Neumark]] (now [[Barlinek]] in [[Poland]]), the son of a [[Hazzan|Jewish cantor]]. At the age of eleven he was sent to Berlin to study mathematics, where he lived with his brother [[Berthold Lasker|Berthold]], eight years his senior, who taught him how to play chess. According to the website [[Chessmetrics]], Berthold was among the world's top ten players in the early 1890s.<ref name="chessmetricsProfileBertholdLasker">{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=199510SSSSS3S073074000000111000000000017510100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Berthold Lasker | publisher=Chessmetrics | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref> To supplement their income Emanuel Lasker played chess and card games for small stakes, especially at the Café Kaiserhof.<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography">{{cite book | title=UXL Encyclopedia of World Biography | editor=Tyle, L.B. | publisher=U·X·L | year=2002 | isbn=0-7876-6465-0 | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_gx5229/is_2003/ai_n19151908 | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref><ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/>
Lasker shot up through the chess rankings in 1889, when he won the Café Kaiserhof's annual Winter tournament 1888/89 and the ''Hauptturnier A'' ("second division" tournament) at the sixth [[DSB Congress|DSB Congress]] (German Chess Federation's congress) held in [[Breslau]]. Winning the Hauptturnier earned Lasker the title of "master". The candidates were divided into two groups of ten. The top four in each group competed in a final. Lasker won his section, with 2½ points more than his nearest rival. However, scores were reset to 0 for the final. With two rounds to go, Lasker trailed the leader, Viennese amateur von Feierfeil, by 1½ points. Lasker won both of his final games, while von Feierfeil lost in the penultimate round (being mated in 121 moves after the position was reconstructed incorrectly following an adjournment) and drew in the last round. The two players were now tied. Lasker won a playoff and garnered the master title. This enabled him to play in master-level tournaments and thus launched his chess career.<ref>"The Start of a Chess Career", from ''Lasker & His Contemporaries'', issue 1, published by Thinkers Press, Inc.</ref>
Lasker finished second in an international tournament at [[Amsterdam]], ahead of some well-known masters, including [[Isidore Gunsberg]] (assessed as the second strongest player in the world at that time by Chessmetrics).<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=199510SSSSS3S048852000000111000000000011010100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Isidor Gunsberg | publisher=Chessmetrics | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] }}</ref><ref name="storiascacchiTornei1880Al1899"/><ref name="Thulin1899WorldChampionshipMatchOrNot">{{cite web|url=http://www.anders.thulin.name/SUBJECTS/CHESS/SteinitzChigorin1889.pdf |title=Steinitz—Chigorin, Havana 1899 - A World Championship Match or Not? |date=August 2007 |format=PDF |author=Thulin, A. |accessdate=2008-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530021654/http://www.anders.thulin.name/SUBJECTS/CHESS/SteinitzChigorin1889.pdf |archivedate=2008-05-30 |df= }}</ref><ref name="storiascacchiMatches1880Al1999"/> In 1890 he finished third in [[Graz]], then shared first prize with his brother Berthold in a tournament in Berlin.<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1880Al1899"/><ref>{{cite book | author=Di Felice, Gino | title=Chess Results, 1747-1900 | publisher=McFarland & Company | year=2004 | pages=121–123 | isbn=0-7864-2041-3 }}</ref> In spring 1892, he won two tournaments in London, the second and stronger of these without losing a game.<ref>{{cite book | author=Di Felice, Gino | title=Chess Results, 1747-1900 | publisher=McFarland & Company | year=2004 | pages=133–134 | isbn=0-7864-2041-3 }}</ref><ref name="Gillam2008London1892Belfast1892"/> At [[New York City]] 1893, he won all thirteen games,<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1880Al1899"/><ref>{{cite book | author=Di Felice, Gino | title=Chess Results, 1747-1900 | publisher=McFarland & Company | year=2004 | page=142 | isbn=0-7864-2041-3 }}</ref><ref name="NYTimes1894PreSteinitzLasker"/> one of the few times in chess history that a player has achieved a [[List of world records in chess#Perfect tournament and match scores|perfect score]] in a significant tournament.<ref>{{cite book | author=Hooper, David | author2=Whyld, Kenneth | author2-link=Kenneth Whyld | title=The Oxford Companion to Chess | publisher=Oxford University Press | page=81 | isbn=0-19-866164-9 | year=1992 | authorlink=David Hooper (chess player) }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Soltis, Andrew | title=Chess Lists Second Edition | publisher=McFarland & Company | year=2002 | pages=81–83 | isbn=0-7864-1296-8 | authorlink=Andrew Soltis }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Sunnucks, Anne | title=The Encyclopaedia of Chess | publisher=St. Martin's Press | year=1970 | page=76 | isbn=0-7091-1030-8 }}</ref>
[[Image:New York 1893 chess tournament.gif|thumb|right|300px|The players and tournament officials at the New York 1893 tournament]] His record in matches was equally impressive: at Berlin in 1890 he drew a short play-off match against his brother Berthold; and won all his other matches from 1889 to 1893, mostly against top-class opponents: [[Curt von Bardeleben]] (1889; ranked 9th best player in the world by Chessmetrics at that time<ref>{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S139455189006131000000000032510100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Curt von Bardeleben | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref>), [[Jacques Mieses]] (1889; ranked 11th<ref>{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S086047189006131000000000019110100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Jacques Mieses | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref>), [[Henry Edward Bird]] (1890; then 60 years old; ranked 29th<ref>{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S012446189006131000000000002610100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Henry Bird | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref>), [[Berthold Englisch]] (1890; ranked 18th<ref>{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S034631189006131000000000007610100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Berthold Englisch | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref>), [[Joseph Henry Blackburne]] (1892, without losing a game; Blackburne was aged 51 then, but still 9th in the world<ref>{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S012785189006131000000000002810100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Joseph Blackburne | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref>), [[Jackson Showalter]] (1892–93; 22nd<ref>{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S121054189006131000000000027110100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Jackson Showalter | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref>) and [[Celso Golmayo Zúpide]] (1893; 29th<ref>{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S045245189006131000000000010610100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Celso Golmayo Zúpide | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref>).<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1880Al1999"/><ref name="chessmetricsCareerDetailsEmanuelLasker"/> Chessmetrics calculates that Emanuel Lasker became the world's strongest player in mid-1890,<ref name="chessmetricsMonthlyLists1885To1895">{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/MonthlyLists.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S073076189006111000000000017510100 | title=Chessmetrics Monthly Lists: 1885–1895 | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref> and that he was in the top ten from the very beginning of his recorded career in 1889.<ref name="chessmetricsSummary1885To1895">{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/Summary.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S073076189006131000000000017510100 | title=Chessmetrics Summary: 1885–1895 | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | publisher=Chessmetrics | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref>
In 1892 Lasker founded the first of his chess magazines, ''The London Chess Fortnightly'', which was published from August 15, 1892 to July 30, 1893. In the second quarter of 1893 there was a gap of ten weeks between issues, allegedly because of problems with the printer.<ref name="LondonChessFortnightly">{{cite book | title=The London Chess Fortnightly | author=Lasker, Emanuel | publisher=Moravian Chess | url=http://www.chesscafe.com/text/review302.pdf | accessdate=2008-06-06 | format=PDF }}</ref> Shortly after its last issue Lasker traveled to the US, where he spent the next two years.<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/>
Lasker challenged [[Siegbert Tarrasch]], who had won three consecutive strong international tournaments ([[Breslau]] 1889, [[Manchester]] 1890, and [[Dresden]] 1892), to a match. Tarrasch haughtily declined, stating that Lasker should first prove his mettle by attempting to win one or two major international events.<ref name="Hannakp.31">{{cite book | author=Hannak, J. | title=Emanuel Lasker: The Life of a Chess Master | publisher=Simon & Schuster | year=1959 | page=31 | isbn=0-486-26706-7 }}</ref>
=== Chess competition 1894–1918 ===
==== Matches against Steinitz ==== [[Image:Wilhelm Steinitz2.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Wilhelm Steinitz]], whom Lasker beat in World Championship matches in 1894 and 1896]] Rebuffed by Tarrasch, Lasker challenged the reigning World Champion [[Wilhelm Steinitz]] to a match for the title.<ref name="Hannakp.31"/> Initially Lasker wanted to play for US $5,000 a side and a match was agreed at stakes of $3,000 a side, but Steinitz agreed to a series of reductions when Lasker found it difficult to raise the money. The final figure was $2,000, which was less than for some of Steinitz' earlier matches (the final combined stake of $4,000 would be worth over $495,000 at 2006 values<ref>Using incomes for the adjustment factor, as the outcome depended on a few months' hard work by the players; if prices are used for the conversion, the result is over $99,000—see {{cite web | url=http://www.measuringworth.com/uscompare/ | title=Six Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a U.S. Dollar Amount, 1774 to Present | publisher=MeasuringWorth | accessdate=2008-05-30 }} However, Lasker later published an analysis showing that the winning player got $1,600 and the losing player $600 out of the $4,000, as the backers who had bet on the winner got the rest: {{cite journal | journal=[[Lasker's Chess Magazine]] | volume=1 | title=From the Editorial Chair |date=January 1905 | url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Lasker%27s_Chess_Magazine/Volume_1 | accessdate=2008-05-31 }}</ref>). Although this was publicly praised as an act of sportsmanship on Steinitz' part,<ref name="NYTimes1894PreSteinitzLasker">{{cite journal | journal=New York Times | date=11 March 1894 | title=Ready for a big chess match | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1894/03/11/106900358.pdf | accessdate=2008-05-30 | format=PDF }} Note: this article implies that the combined stake was $4,500, but Lasker wrote that it was $4,000: {{cite journal | journal=[[Lasker's Chess Magazine]] | volume=1 |date=January 1905 | url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Lasker%27s_Chess_Magazine/Volume_1 | title=From the Editorial Chair | accessdate=2008-05-31 }}</ref> Steinitz may have desperately needed the money.<ref name="chessvilleSteinitzPapers">{{cite web | url=http://www.chessville.com/reviews/SteinitzPapers.htm | title=The Steinitz Papers - review | publisher=ChessVille | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref> The match was played in 1894, at venues in New York, [[Philadelphia]], and [[Montreal]]. Steinitz had previously declared he would win without doubt, so it came as a shock when Lasker won the first game. Steinitz responded by winning the second, and maintained the balance through the sixth. However, Lasker won all the games from the seventh to the eleventh, and Steinitz asked for a week's rest. When the match resumed, Steinitz looked in better shape and won the 13th and 14th games. Lasker struck back in the 15th and 16th, and Steinitz did not compensate for his losses in the middle of the match. Hence Lasker [[World Chess Championship 1894|won convincingly]] with ten wins, five losses and four [[draw (chess)|draws]].<ref>{{cite book | author=Kažić, B. M. | title=International Championship Chess: A Complete Record of FIDE Events | publisher=Pitman | year=1974 | page=212 | isbn=0-273-07078-9 }}</ref><ref name="Giffard394">{{cite book | author=Giffard, Nicolas | year=1993 | title=Le Guide des Échecs | language=French | publisher=[[Éditions Robert Laffont]] | page=394 }}</ref><ref name="chessvilleSteinitzLasker1894">{{cite web | url=http://www.chessville.com/instruction/Lasker_v_Steinitz/instr_annogames_laskervsteinitz1894.htm | title=Lasker v. Steinitz - World Championship Match 1894 | publisher=ChessVille | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref> Lasker thus became the second formally recognized [[World Chess Champion]], and confirmed his title by beating Steinitz even more convincingly in their re-match in 1896–97 (ten wins, two losses, and five draws).<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1880Al1999"/><ref>{{cite book | author=Kažić, B. M. | title=International Championship Chess: A Complete Record of FIDE Events | publisher=Pitman | year=1974 | page=213 | isbn=0-273-07078-9 }}</ref>
==== Tournament successes ==== [[File:ELasker.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Sketch of Lasker, c. 1894]] Influential players and journalists belittled the 1894 match both before and after it took place. Lasker's difficulty in getting backing may have been caused by hostile pre-match comments from Gunsberg and [[Leopold Hoffer]],<ref name="NYTimes1894PreSteinitzLasker"/> who had long been a bitter enemy of Steinitz.<ref name="WinterKKSCotch">{{cite web | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/scotch.html | title=Kasparov, Karpov and the Scotch | author=Winter, E. | publisher=ChessHistory | accessdate=2008-05-30 }}</ref> One of the complaints was that Lasker had never played the other two members of the top four, [[Siegbert Tarrasch]] and [[Mikhail Chigorin]]<ref name="NYTimes1894PreSteinitzLasker"/> – although Tarrasch had rejected a challenge from Lasker in 1892, publicly telling him to go and win an international tournament first.<ref name="LondonChessFortnightly"/><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.chess-poster.com/great_players/lasker.htm |title = Emanuel Lasker |accessdate = 2008-06-05 |publisher = Chess-Poster |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080527203548/http://www.chess-poster.com/great_players/lasker.htm |archivedate = 2008-05-27 |df = }}</ref> After the match, some commentators, notably Tarrasch, said Lasker had won mainly because Steinitz was old (58 in 1894).<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.chesscorner.com/worldchamps/lasker/lasker.htm | title=Chess World Champions – Emanuel Lasker | accessdate=2008-11-21 | publisher=ChessCorner }}</ref>
Emanuel Lasker answered these criticisms by creating an even more impressive playing record. Before [[World War I]] broke out, his most serious "setbacks" were third place at [[Hastings 1895 chess tournament|Hastings 1895]] (where he may have been suffering from the after-effects of [[typhoid fever]]<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/>), a tie for second at [[1904 Cambridge Springs International Chess Congress|Cambridge Springs 1904]], and a tie for first at the [[Chigorin Memorial]] in [[St Petersburg]] 1909.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker">{{cite book | author=Fine, Reuben | title=The World's Great Chess Games | chapter=Emanuel Lasker | year=1952 | publisher=Andre Deutsch (now as paperback from Dover) | isbn=0-679-13046-2 | authorlink=Reuben Fine }}</ref> He won first prizes at very strong tournaments in St Petersburg (1895–96, ''Quadrangular''), [[Nuremberg 1896 chess tournament|Nuremberg (1896)]], [[London 1899 chess tournament|London (1899)]], [[Paris 1900 chess tournament|Paris (1900)]] and [[St. Petersburg 1914 chess tournament|St Petersburg (1914)]], where he overcame a 1½-point deficit to finish ahead of the rising stars, Capablanca and [[Alexander Alekhine]], who later became the next two World Champions.<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1880Al1899"/><ref name="chessmetricsCareerDetailsEmanuelLasker"/><ref name="storiascacchiTornei1900Al1909"/><ref name="storiascacchiTornei1910Al1919"/><ref>For good measure he also took first prize in a weaker tournament at Trenton Falls in 1906.</ref> For decades chess writers have reported that [[Tsar]] [[Nicholas II of Russia]] conferred the title of "[[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster of Chess]]" upon each of the five finalists at St Petersburg 1914 (Lasker, Capablanca, Alekhine, Tarrasch and [[Frank Marshall (chess player)|Marshall]]), but chess historian [[Edward Winter (chess historian)|Edward Winter]] has questioned this, stating that the earliest known sources supporting this story were published in 1940 and 1942.<ref name="KCAK">{{Cite book | last1=Winter | first1=Edward | author1-link=Edward Winter (chess historian) | year=1999 | title=Kings, Commoners and Knaves: Further Chess Explorations | edition=1 | publisher=Russell Enterprises, Inc. | isbn=1-888690-04-6 | pages=315–316 }}</ref><ref name="Chess Omnibus">{{Cite book | last1=Winter | first1=Edward | author1-link=Edward Winter (chess historian) | year=2003 | title=A Chess Omnibus | edition=1 | publisher=Russell Enterprises, Inc. | isbn=1-888690-17-8 | pages=177–178 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/winter38.html#5144._Tsar_Nicholas_II | accessdate=2008-11-21 | title=Chess Note 5144: Tsar Nicholas II | publisher=ChessHistory | author=Winter, Edward }}</ref>
==== Matches against Marshall and Tarrasch ==== {{main|World Chess Championship 1907|World Chess Championship 1908}} Lasker's match record was as impressive between his 1896–97 re-match with Steinitz and 1914: he won all but one of his normal matches, and three of those were convincing defenses of his title. He first faced Marshall in the [[World Chess Championship 1907]], when despite his aggressive style, Marshall could not win a single game, losing eight and drawing seven (final score: 11½−3½).<ref name="Giffard396">Giffard, p.396</ref>
He then played Tarrasch in the [[World Chess Championship 1908]], first at [[Düsseldorf]] then at [[Munich]]. Tarrasch firmly believed the game of chess was governed by a precise set of principles.<ref name="Giffard396"/> For him the strength of a chess move was in its logic, not in its efficiency. Because of his stubborn principles he considered Lasker as a {{chessgloss|coffeehouse|coffeehouse player}} who won his games only thanks to dubious tricks, while Lasker mocked the arrogance of Tarrasch who, in his opinion, shone more in [[Salon (gathering)|salons]] than at the chessboard. At the opening ceremony, Tarrasch refused to talk to Lasker, only saying: "Mr. Lasker, I have only three words to say to you: check and mate!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.atlantic-times.com/archive_detail.php?recordID=1509 |author=Stefan Löffler |publisher=The Atlantic Times |title=Check and Mate |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524004826/http://www.atlantic-times.com/archive_detail.php?recordID=1509 |archivedate=2011-05-24 |df= }}</ref><ref>Giffard, p.397</ref>
{{Chess diagram small |tright |Tarrasch vs. Lasker, <br />World Championship 1908<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1241474 |title=Tarrasch vs. Lasker, World Championship 1908}} [[Chessgames.com]]</ref> | | | |rd|rd| | |kd |ql| |pd|qd|bd| | |pd | | |pd|pd| |pd| | | | | | | |nl| | | | | | |pl| | | | |pl| | | | | | |pl| |pl| | |kl|pl|pl |rl| | | |rl| | | |Position after 19.Qxa7 }} Lasker gave a brilliant answer on the chessboard, winning four of the first five games, and playing a type of chess Tarrasch could not understand. For example, in the second game after 19 moves arose a situation (see diagram) in which Lasker was a [[pawn (chess)|pawn]] down, with a {{chessgloss|bad bishop}} and {{chessgloss|doubled pawns}}. At this point it appeared Tarrasch was winning, but 20 moves later he was forced to [[resign (chess)|resign]].<ref name="Giffard398">Giffard, p.398</ref> Lasker eventually won by 10½−5½ (eight wins, five draws, and three losses). Tarrasch claimed the wet weather was the cause of his defeat.<ref name="Giffard398"/>
==== Matches against Janowski ==== {{main|World Chess Championship 1910 (Lasker–Janowski)}}
In 1909 Lasker drew a short match (two wins, two losses) against [[Dawid Janowski]], an all-out attacking [[Polish people|Polish]] expatriate. Several months later they played a longer match in Paris, and chess historians still debate whether this was for the World Chess Championship.<ref>Several authors have considered this match as a World Chess Championship, for instance: *{{cite book | title=From Morphy to Fischer | author=Horowitz, Israel | publisher=Batsford | year=1973 | pages=63–64 | authorlink=Israel Horowitz}} *{{cite book | title=The Centenary Match – Kasparov-Karpov III | author=Keene, Raymond | author2=Goodman, David | publisher=Batsford | page=6 | year=1986 | isbn=0-02-028700-3 | authorlink=Raymond Keene}} *{{cite book | title=Le guide des échecs | author=Giffard, Nicolas | language=French | year=1993 | publisher=[[Éditions Robert Laffont]] | page=400}} More recent sources consider it was only an exhibition match: *{{cite web | author=Edward Winter | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/winter38.html#5199._Lasker_v_Janowsky_Paris_1909 | title=Chess Notes 5199 | publisher=ChessHistory.com | authorlink=Edward Winter (chess historian)}} *{{cite web | author=Mark Weeks | title=1909 Lasker - Janowski Exhibition Matches | publisher=mark-weeks.com | url=http://www.mark-weeks.com/chess/09lj$wix.htm}}</ref> Understanding Janowski's style, Lasker chose to defend solidly so that Janowski unleashed his attacks too soon and left himself vulnerable. Lasker easily won the match 8–2 (seven wins, two draws, one loss).<ref name="Giffard400">{{cite book | title=Le guide des échecs | author=Giffard, Nicolas | language=French | year=1993 | publisher=[[Éditions Robert Laffont]] | page=400}}</ref> This victory was convincing for everyone but Janowski, who asked for a revenge match. Lasker accepted and they played a [[World Chess Championship 1910 (Lasker–Janowski)|World Chess Championship match]] in Berlin in November–December 1910. Lasker crushed his opponent, winning 9½−1½ (eight wins, three draws, no losses).<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1900Al1914"/> Janowski did not understand Lasker's moves, and after his first three losses he declared to [[Edward Lasker]], "Your [[homonym]] plays so stupidly that I cannot even look at the chessboard when he thinks. I am afraid I will not do anything good in this match."<ref name="Giffard400"/>
==== Match against Schlechter ==== {{main|World Chess Championship 1910 (Lasker–Schlechter)}} [[Image:Carl Schlechter (profile).png|thumb|upright|Schlechter would have taken Lasker's world title if he had won or drawn the last game of their 1910 match.]] Between his two matches against Janowski, Lasker arranged another [[World Chess Championship 1910 (Lasker–Schlechter)|World Chess Championship]] in January–February 1910 against [[Carl Schlechter]]. Schlechter was a modest gentleman, who was generally unlikely to win the major chess tournaments by his peaceful inclination, his lack of aggressiveness and his willingness to accept most [[draw (chess)|draw]] [[draw by agreement|offers]] from his opponents (about 80% of his games finished by a draw).<ref name="Giffard404">Giffard 1993, p. 404</ref> According to Isaak and Vladimir Linder, the match was originally to be a 30 game affair and Schlecter would have to win by a two game margin. They note that the Austrian chess historian Micheal Ehn has established, based on the Viennese sources, that Lasker agreed to forgo the plus two provision in view of the match being subsequently reduced to only 10 games. For proof Ehn quoted Schlechter's comment printed in Allgemeine Sportzeitung (ASZ) of December 9, 1909 "There will be ten games in all. The winner on points will receive the title of world champion. If the points are equal, the decision will be made by the arbiter." <ref> {{cite book | title=Emanuel Lasker, 2nd World Chess Champion | author=Isaak and Vladimir Linder | publisher=Russel Enterprises Inc. | date=2010 | page=109 }} </ref>
At the beginning, Lasker tried to attack but Schlechter had no difficulty defending, so that the first four games finished in draws. In the fifth game Lasker had a big advantage, but committed a blunder that cost him the game. Hence at the middle of the match Schlechter was one point ahead. The next four games were drawn, despite fierce play from both players. In the sixth Schlechter managed to draw a game being a pawn down. In the seventh Lasker nearly lost because of a beautiful [[The exchange (chess)#The exchange sacrifice|exchange sacrifice]] from Schlechter. In the ninth only a blunder from Lasker allowed Schlechter to draw a lost [[chess endgame|ending]]. The score before the last game was thus 5–4 for Schlechter. In the tenth game Schlechter tried to win tactically and took a big advantage, but he missed a clear win at the 35th move, continued to take increasing risks and finished by losing.<ref name="Giffard406">Giffard 1993, p. 406</ref> Hence the match was a draw and Lasker remained World Champion.
==== Abandoned challenges ==== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Capablanca3.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[José Raúl Capablanca]] won the world title from Lasker in 1921]] --> In 1911 Lasker received a challenge for a world title match against the rising star [[José Raúl Capablanca]]. Lasker was unwilling to play the traditional "first to win ten games" type of match in the semi-tropical conditions of [[Havana]], especially as drawn games were becoming more frequent and the match might last for over six months. He therefore made a counter-proposal: if neither player had a lead of at least two games by the end of the match, it should be considered a draw; the match should be limited to the best of thirty games, counting draws; except that if either player won six games ''and'' led by at least two games before thirty games were completed, he should be declared the winner; the champion should decide the venue and stakes, and should have the exclusive right to publish the games; the challenger should deposit a forfeit of US $2,000 (equivalent to over $194,000 in 2006 values<ref>Using average incomes as the conversion factor; if prices are used for the conversion, the result is about $45,000—see {{cite web | url=http://www.measuringworth.com/uscompare/ | title=Six Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a U.S. Dollar Amount, 1774 to Present | publisher=MeasuringWorth | accessdate=2008-06-05 }}</ref>); the time limit should be twelve moves per hour; play should be limited to two sessions of 2½ hours each per day, five days a week. Capablanca objected to the time limit, the short playing times, the thirty-game limit, and especially the requirement that he must win by two games to claim the title, which he regarded as unfair. Lasker took offence at the terms in which Capablanca criticized the two-game lead condition and broke off negotiations, and until 1914 Lasker and Capablanca were not on speaking terms. However, at the 1914 St. Petersburg tournament, Capablanca proposed a set of rules for the conduct of World Championship matches, which were accepted by all the leading players, including Lasker.<ref name="graemecree1921WorldChessChampionship">{{Cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050120165616/http://members.aol.com/graemecree/chesschamps/world/world1921.htm | title=1921 World Chess Championship | accessdate=2008-11-21 | archivedate=January 20, 2005 | url=http://members.aol.com/graemecree/chesschamps/world/world1921.htm }} This cites: a report of Lasker's concerns about the location and duration of the match, in the ''New York Evening Post'', March 15, 1911; Capablanca's letter of December 20, 1911 to Lasker, stating his objections to Lasker's proposal; Lasker's letter to Capablanca, breaking off negotiations; Lasker's letter of April 27, 1921 to Alberto Ponce of the Havana Chess Club, proposing to resign the 1921 match; and Ponce's reply, accepting the resignation.</ref>
Late in 1912 Lasker entered into negotiations for a world title match with [[Akiba Rubinstein]], whose tournament record for the previous few years had been on a par with Lasker's and a little ahead of Capablanca's.<ref name="chessmetricsProfileRubinstein">{{cite web | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S112008189006131000000000026310100 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Akiba Rubinstein | publisher=Chessmetrics | author=[[Jeff Sonas]] | accessdate=2008-06-04 }}</ref> The two players agreed to play a match if Rubinstein could raise the funds, but Rubinstein had few rich friends to back him and the match was never played. This situation demonstrated some of the flaws inherent in the championship system then being used. The start of World War I in summer 1914 put an end to hopes that Lasker would play either Rubinstein or Capablanca for the World Championship in the near future.<ref name="Horowitz1973MorphyToFischer">{{cite book | title=From Morphy to Fischer | author=Horowitz, I.A. | publisher=Batsford | year=1973 | authorlink=Israel Horowitz }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=Classical Chess Matches, 1907–1913 | author=Wilson, F. | year=1975 | publisher=Dover | isbn=0-486-23145-3 }}</ref> Throughout World War I (1914–1918) Lasker played in only two serious chess events. He convincingly won (5½−½) a non-title match against Tarrasch in 1916.<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1915Al1929"/> In September–October 1918, shortly before the [[Armistice with Germany (Compiègne)|armistice]], he won a quadrangular (four-player) tournament, half a point ahead of Rubinstein.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.endgame.nl/berlin1928.htm |title = Berlin 1897, 1918 and 1928 |publisher = Endgame |accessdate = 2008-06-05 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080619004619/http://www.endgame.nl/berlin1928.htm |archivedate = 2008-06-19 |df = }}</ref>
=== Academic activities 1894–1918 === [[Image:Hilbert.jpg|thumb|upright|[[David Hilbert]] encouraged Lasker to obtain a [[Ph.D]] in mathematics.]] Despite his superb playing results, chess was not Lasker's only interest. His parents recognized his intellectual talents, especially for mathematics, and sent the adolescent Emanuel to study in Berlin (where he found he also had a talent for chess). Lasker gained his [[abitur]] (high school graduation certificate) at [[Landsberg an der Warthe]], now a [[Poland|Polish]] town named Gorzów Wielkopolski but then part of [[Prussia]]. He then studied mathematics and philosophy at the universities in Berlin, [[Göttingen]] (where [[David Hilbert]] was one of his doctoral advisors) and [[Heidelberg]].<ref name="dcsStAndrewsLaskerBio"/>
In 1895 Lasker published two mathematical articles in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]''.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Metrical Relations of Plane Spaces of ''n'' Manifoldness | author=Lasker, Emanuel | journal=Nature | volume=52 | issue=1345 | pages=340–343 |date=August 1895 | doi=10.1038/052340d0 | url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/052340d0 | accessdate=2008-05-31 |bibcode = 1895Natur..52R.340L }}<br/>{{cite journal | title=About a certain Class of Curved Lines in Space of ''n'' Manifoldness | author=Lasker, Emanuel | journal=Nature | volume=52 | issue=1355 |date=October 1895 | pages=596–596 | doi=10.1038/052596a0 | url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/052596a0 | accessdate=2008-05-31 |bibcode = 1895Natur..52..596L }}</ref> On the advice of [[David Hilbert]] he registered for doctoral studies at [[Erlangen]] during 1900–1902.<ref name="dcsStAndrewsLaskerBio"/> In 1901 he presented his doctoral thesis ''Über Reihen auf der Convergenzgrenze'' ("On Series at Convergence Boundaries") at Erlangen and in the same year it was published by the [[Royal Society]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Great Chess Upsets | author=Reshevsky, Samuel | publisher=Arco | year=1976 | isbn=0-668-03492-0 | authorlink=Samuel Reshevsky }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A | title=Über Reihen auf der Convergenzgrenze | author=Lasker, Emanuel | year=1901 | volume=196 | issue=274–286 | pages=431–477 | bibcode=1901RSPTA.196..431L | doi=10.1098/rsta.1901.0009 }}</ref> He was awarded a doctorate in mathematics in 1902.<ref name="dcsStAndrewsLaskerBio"/> His most significant mathematical article, in 1905, published a [[Lasker–Noether theorem|theorem]] of which [[Emmy Noether]] developed a more generalized form, which is now regarded as of fundamental importance to modern [[algebra]] and [[algebraic geometry]].<ref>{{Cite journal |first = E. |last = Lasker |title = Zur Theorie der Moduln und Ideale |journal = Math. Ann. |volume = 60 |year = 1905 |issue = 1 |pages = 20–116 |doi = 10.1007/BF01447495 |url = http://gdz.sub.uni-goettingen.de/index.php?id=11&PPN=PPN235181684_0060&DMDID=DMDLOG_0008&L=1 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}<br/>{{Cite journal |author1-link = Emmy Noether |title = Idealtheorie in Ringbereichen |year = 1921 |journal = [[Mathematische Annalen]] |volume = 83 |issue = 1 |doi = 10.1007/BF01464225 |author = Noether, Emmy |pages = 24–66 |url = http://gdz.sub.uni-goettingen.de/index.php?id=11&PPN=PPN235181684_0083&DMDID=DMDLOG_0008&L=1 |bibcode = 1921MatAn..83...24N |access-date = 2013-09-30 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160305071858/http://gdz.sub.uni-goettingen.de/index.php?id=11&PPN=PPN235181684_0083&DMDID=DMDLOG_0008&L=1 |archive-date = 2016-03-05 |dead-url = yes |df = }} For the relationship between Lasker's work and Noether's see {{cite web |url = http://eom.springer.de/L/l057600.htm |title = Springer Online Reference Works: Lasker ring |publisher = Springer |accessdate = 2008-05-31 }}</ref><ref name="dcsStAndrewsLaskerBio"/>
Lasker held short-term positions as a mathematics lecturer at [[Tulane University]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] (1893) and [[Victoria University of Manchester|Victoria University]] in [[Manchester]] (1901; Victoria University was one of the "parents" of the current [[University of Manchester]]).<ref name="dcsStAndrewsLaskerBio"/> However, he was unable to secure a longer-term position, and pursued his scholarly interests independently.<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches">{{cite web |url = http://www.lasker-gesellschaft.de/forum/johannes-fischer/lasker-new-approaches.html |title = Lasker: New Approaches |publisher = Lasker-Gesellschaft |accessdate = 2008-11-21 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/6190wVQxf?url=http://www.lasker-gesellschaft.de/forum/johannes-fischer/lasker-new-approaches.html |archive-date = 2011-08-23 |dead-url = yes |df = }}; also available at {{cite web |url = http://www.chesscafe.com/text/skittles158.pdf |title = Lasker: New Approaches |publisher = ChessCafe |accessdate = 2008-05-02 |format = PDF }}. This refers to {{cite book | title=Emanuel Lasker: Schach, Philosophie und Wissenschaft (Emanuel Lasker: Chess, Philosophy and Science) | author=Sieg, Ulrich | author2=Dreyer, Michael | publisher=Philo | year=2001 | isbn=3-8257-0216-2 }}.</ref>
In 1906 Lasker published a booklet titled ''Kampf'' (''Struggle''),<ref name="Lasker1906Kampf">Many sources say ''Kampf'' was published in 1907, but Lasker said 1906 - {{cite book | title=Lasker's Manual of Chess | author=Lasker, Emanuel |origyear=1932 |date=1960 | publisher=Courier Dover | isbn=0-486-20640-8 }}</ref> in which he attempted to create a general theory of all competitive activities, including chess, business and war. He produced two other books which are generally categorized as philosophy, ''Das Begreifen der Welt'' (''Comprehending the World''; 1913) and ''Die Philosophie des Unvollendbar'' (sic; ''The Philosophy of the Unattainable''; 1918).<ref name="dcsStAndrewsLaskerBio"/>
=== Other activities 1894–1918 === In 1896–97 Lasker published his book ''Common Sense in Chess'', based on lectures he had given in London in 1895.<ref>{{cite book | title=Common Sense in Chess | author=Lasker, Emanuel |origyear=1896 (German edition) |date=1965 | publisher=Courier Dover | isbn=0-486-21440-0 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=1MP1FhWELmAC&dq=%22common+sense+in+chess%22+lasker | accessdate=2008-05-02 }}</ref>
{{Chess diagram small | tright | [[Rice Gambit]]
|rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|__|__|rd |pd|pd|pd|__|__|pd|__|pd |__|__|__|bd|__|nd|__|__ |__|__|__|pl|nl|__|__|__ |__|__|bl|__|__|pd|pd|pl |__|__|__|__|__|__|__|__ |pl|pl|pl|pl|__|__|pl|__ |rl|nl|bl|ql|__|rl|kl|__ | {{hidden|multiline=y|ta1=left|fw1=normal| Position after 1.e4 e5 2.f4 exf4 3.Nf3 g5 4.h4 g4 5.Ne5 Nf6 6.Bc4 d5 7.exd5 Bd6 8.0-0 | White [[sacrifice (chess)|sacrifices]] the knight on e5 in order to get his king to safety and enable a rook to join the attack against the under-developed black position.}} }} {{algebraic notation|pos=egright}}
In 1903, Lasker played in [[Ostend]] against [[Mikhail Chigorin]], a six-game match that was sponsored by the wealthy lawyer and industrialist [[Isaac Rice]] in order to test the [[Rice Gambit]].<ref>{{cite journal | journal=New York Times | title=Chess World's Doings; Lasker to Test Rice Gambit | date=August 2, 1903 | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1903/08/02/101312061.pdf | accessdate=2008-05-02 | format=PDF }}</ref> Lasker narrowly lost the match. Three years later Lasker became secretary of the Rice Gambit Association, founded by Rice in order to promote the Rice Gambit,<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/> and in 1907 Lasker quoted with approval Rice's views on the convergence of chess and military strategy.<ref>{{Cite journal | pages=35 | journal=Lasker's Chess Magazine | date=November 1907 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/winter29.html | title=Chess Notes by Edward Winter | accessdate=2008-05-02 }}</ref>
In November 1904, Lasker founded ''Lasker's Chess Magazine'', which ran until 1909.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://moravian-chess.cz/katalog.php?idkat=11 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070704013603/http://www.moravian-chess.cz/katalog.php?idkat=11 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2007-07-04 |title = Moravian chess publishing - Catalogue |publisher = Moravian Chess |accessdate = 2008-05-02 }}</ref>
For a short time in 1906 Emanuel Lasker was interested in the strategy game [[Go (board game)|Go]], but soon returned to chess. He was introduced to the game by his namesake [[Edward Lasker]], who wrote a successful book ''Go and Go-Moku'' in 1934.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/rec.games.go/LGH6DOZtaZc|title=Google Groups|website=groups.google.com|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref>
At the age of 42, in July 1911, Lasker married Martha Cohn (née Bamberger), a rich widow who was a year older than Lasker and already a grandmother. They lived in Berlin.<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/><ref>{{cite book | title=Emanuel Lasker: The Life of a Chess Master | author=Hannak, J. | publisher=Simon & Schuster | year=1959 | pages=152, 160–61 | isbn= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Hooper, D. | author2=Whyld, K. | title=[[The Oxford Companion to Chess]] | edition=2 | year=1992 | page=218 | isbn=0-19-866164-9 }}</ref> Martha Cohn wrote popular stories under the pseudonym "L. Marco".<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/><ref>{{cite book | title=Emanuel Lasker: The Life of a Chess Master | author=Hannak, J. | publisher=Simon & Schuster | year=1959 | page=125 | isbn= }}</ref>
During [[World War I]], Lasker invested all of his savings in German [[war bond]]s, which lost nearly their entire value with the wartime and [[hyperinflation in the Weimar Republic|post-war inflation]]. During the war, he wrote a pamphlet which claimed that civilization would be in danger if Germany lost the war.<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/>
=== Match against Capablanca === {{main|World Chess Championship 1921|}} In January 1920 Lasker and [[José Raúl Capablanca]] signed an agreement to play a World Championship match in 1921, noting that Capablanca was not free to play in 1920. Because of the delay, Lasker insisted on a final clause that allowed him to play anyone else for the championship in 1920, that nullified the contract with Capablanca if Lasker lost a title match in 1920, and that stipulated that if Lasker resigned the title Capablanca should become World Champion. Lasker had previously included in his agreement before World War I to play [[Akiba Rubinstein]] for the title a similar clause that if he resigned the title, it should become Rubinstein's.<ref name="WinterHowCapaBecameChampion"/>
A report in the ''American Chess Bulletin'' (July–August 1920 issue) said that Lasker had resigned the world title in favor of Capablanca because the conditions of the match were unpopular in the chess world. The ''American Chess Bulletin'' speculated that the conditions were not sufficiently unpopular to warrant resignation of the title, and that Lasker's real concern was that there was not enough financial backing to justify his devoting nine months to the match.<ref name="WinterHowCapaBecameChampion">{{cite web | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/capablanca2.html | title=How Capablanca Became World Champion | author=Winter, Edward | publisher=ChessHistory | accessdate=2008-06-05 | authorlink=Edward Winter (chess historian) }} Winter cites: ''American Chess Bulletin'' (July–August 1920 issue) for Lasker's resignation of the title, the ''ACB''{{'s}} theory about Lasker's real motive and Havana's offer of $20,000; [[Amos Burn]] in ''The Field'' of 3 July 1920, the ''British Chess Magazine'' of August 1920 and other sources for protestations that Lasker had no right to nominate a successor; [[Amos Burn]] in ''The Field'' of 3 July 1920 and E.S. Tinsley in ''The Times'' (London) of 26 June 1920 for criticism of the conditions Lasker set for the defense of the title; ''American Chess Bulletin'' September–October 1920 for Lasker's and Capablanca's statements that Capablanca was the champion and Lasker the challenger, for Capablanca's statement that Lasker's contract with Rubinstein had contained a clause allowing him to abdicate in favor of Rubinstein, for Lasker's intention to resign the title if he beat Capablanca and his support for an international organization, preferably based in the Americas, to manage international chess. Winter says that before Lasker's abdication some chess correspondents had been calling for Lasker to be stripped of the title. For a very detailed account given by Capablanca after the match, see {{Cite journal | journal=British Chess Magazine | author=Capablanca, José Raúl | date=October 1922 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/capablancalasker.html | title=Capablanca's Reply to Lasker (presented by Edward Winter) | accessdate=2008-06-05 | authorlink=José Raúl Capablanca }}</ref> When Lasker resigned the title in favor of Capablanca he was unaware that enthusiasts in [[Havana]] had just raised $20,000 to fund the match provided it was played there. When Capablanca learned of Lasker's resignation he went to the Netherlands, where Lasker was living at the time, to inform him that Havana would finance the match. In August 1920 Lasker agreed to play in Havana, but insisted that he was the challenger as Capablanca was now the champion. Capablanca signed an agreement that accepted this point, and soon afterwards published a letter confirming this. Lasker also stated that, if he beat Capablanca, he would resign the title so that younger masters could compete for it.<ref name="WinterHowCapaBecameChampion"/>
The match was played in March–April 1921. After four draws, the fifth game saw Lasker [[blunder (chess)|blunder]] with Black in an equal [[chess endgame|ending]]. Capablanca's solid style allowed him to easily draw the next four games, without taking any risks. In the tenth game, Lasker as White played a position with an [[Isolated Queen Pawn|isolated queen pawn]] but failed to create the necessary activity and Capablanca reached a superior ending, which he duly won. The eleventh and fourteenth games were also won by Capablanca, and Lasker resigned the match.<ref>{{cite book | title=Le guide des échecs | author=Giffard, Nicolas | language=French | year=1993 | publisher=[[Éditions Robert Laffont]] | page=412 }}</ref>
[[Reuben Fine]] and [[Harry Golombek]] attributed this to Lasker's being in mysteriously poor form.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/><ref>{{cite book | author=Golombek, H. | chapter=On the Way to the World Championship |page=59 | title=Capablanca's Hundred Best Games of Chess | editor=Golombek, H. | publisher=G. Bell & Sons | year=1959 | isbn=0-679-14044-1 }}</ref> On the other hand, [[Vladimir Kramnik]] thought that Lasker played quite well and the match was an "even and fascinating fight" until Lasker blundered in the last game, and explained that Capablanca was 20 years younger, a slightly stronger player, and had more recent competitive practice.<ref name="KramnikSteinitzToKasparov"/>
=== European life and travels === Lasker was in his early 50s when he lost the world championship to Capablanca, and he retired from serious match play afterwards;<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1915Al1929"/><ref name="storiascacchiMatches1930Al1949">{{cite web | url=http://xoomer.virgilio.it/cserica/scacchi/storiascacchi/matches/1930-49.htm | title=I matches 1930/49 | publisher=La grande storia degli scacchi | accessdate=2009-09-03 }}</ref> his only other match was a short exhibition against [[Frank James Marshall]] in 1940, which Lasker lost. After winning the [[Moravská Ostrava 1923 chess tournament]] (without a single loss), the [[New York 1924 chess tournament]] (1½ points ahead of Capablanca) and finishing second at Moscow in 1925 (1½ points behind [[Efim Bogoljubow]], ½ point ahead of Capablanca),<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1920Al1929"/> he effectively retired from serious chess.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/>
[[Image:Lasker.png|thumb|Emanuel Lasker (left) and his brother [[Berthold Lasker]] in 1907]] During the [[Moscow 1925 chess tournament]], Emanuel Lasker received a telegram informing him that the drama written by himself and his brother [[Berthold Lasker|Berthold]], ''Vom Menschen die Geschichte'' ("History of Mankind"), had been accepted for performance at the Lessing theatre in Berlin. Emanuel Lasker was so distracted by this news that he lost badly to [[Carlos Torre]] the same day.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=3779 | title=Production of Lasker trainer cancelled | publisher=ChessBase | accessdate=2008-05-02 }} includes an image of part of the original newspaper report.</ref> The play, however, was not a success.<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/>
In 1926, Lasker wrote ''Lehrbuch des Schachspiels'', which he re-wrote in English in 1927 as ''[[Lasker's Manual of Chess]]''.<ref name="LaskersManualOfChess">{{cite book | title=Lasker's Manual of Chess | author=Lasker, Emanuel | publisher=Dover | origyear=1927 |date=1960 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=vNXFc-JWpH0C&dq=%22lasker%27s+manual+of+chess%22&pg=PP1 | accessdate=2008-06-06 | isbn=0-486-20640-8 }}</ref> He also wrote books on other games of mental skill: ''Encyclopedia of Games'' (1929) and ''Das verständige Kartenspiel'' (means "Sensible Card Play"; 1929; English translation in the same year), both of which posed a problem in the [[Mathematical game|mathematical analysis of card games]];<ref name="Wastlund2005TwoPersonSingleSuitWhist">{{cite journal | title=A solution of two-person single-suit whist | author=Johan Wăstlund | journal=The Electronic Journal of Combinatorics | volume=12 | date=September 5, 2005 | url=http://www.emis.de/journals/EJC/Volume_12/PDF/v12i1r43.pdf | accessdate=2008-06-06 | format=PDF }}</ref> ''Brettspiele der Völker'' ("Board Games of the Nations"; 1931), which includes 30 pages about [[Go (board game)|Go]] and a section about a game he had invented in 1911, [[Lasca]].<ref name="ResearchInterfaceLasca">{{cite web |url = http://research.interface.co.uk/lasca/about.htm |title = About Lasca – a little-known abstract game |accessdate = 2008-06-06 |publisher = Human–Computer Interface Research |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080509062029/http://research.interface.co.uk/lasca/about.htm |archivedate = 2008-05-09 |df = }}</ref>
In 1930, Lasker was a special correspondent for Dutch and German newspapers<ref name=Culbertson>{{cite book | last = Culbertson | first = Ely | authorlink = Ely Culbertson | title = The Strange Lives of One Man | publisher = The John C. Winston Company | pages = 552–553| location = Chicago | year= 1940 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/culbertson.html}}</ref> reporting on the [[Ely Culbertson#Anglo-American matches|Culbertson-Buller]] bridge match during which he became a registered teacher of the [[Ely Culbertson|Culbertson]] system.<ref name=Culbertson/> He became an expert bridge player,<ref name=Laskeratbridge/> representing Germany at international events in the early 1930s,<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/><ref name="Giffard394"/> and wrote ''Das Bridgespiel'' ("The Game of [[Contract bridge|Bridge]]") in 1931.<ref name="WinterBridge">{{cite web | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/bridge.html | title=Chess and Bridge | publisher=ChessHistory | accessdate=2008-06-06 }}</ref>
In October 1928 Emanuel Lasker's brother [[Berthold Lasker|Berthold]] died.<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/><ref>{{cite book | title=Emanuel Lasker: The Life of a Chess Master | author=Hannak, J. | publisher=Simon and Schuster | year=1959 | page=266 | isbn=0-486-26706-7 }}</ref>
In spring 1933 [[Adolf Hitler]] started a campaign of [[Nazi boycott of Jewish businesses|discrimination and intimidation]] against [[Jew]]s, depriving them of their property and [[citizenship]]. Lasker and his wife Martha, who were both Jewish, were forced to leave Germany in the same year.<ref>{{cite book | author=Hannak, J. | title=Emanuel Lasker: The Life of a Chess Master | publisher=Simon & Schuster | year=1959 | page=268 | isbn=0-486-26706-7 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Hooper, D. | author2=Whyld, K. | title=The Oxford Companion to Chess | edition=2 | year=1992 | page=218 | isbn=0-19-866164-9 }}</ref> After a short stay in England, in 1935 they were invited to live in the USSR by [[Nikolai Krylenko]], the Commissar of Justice who was responsible for the [[Show trial|Moscow show trials]] and, in his other capacity as Sports Minister, was an enthusiastic supporter of chess.<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/> In the USSR, Lasker renounced his German citizenship and received Soviet citizenship.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Litmanowicz, Władysław |author2=Giżycki, Jerzy | title=Szachy od A do Z | publisher=Wydawnictwo ''Sport i Turystyka'' Warszawa | year=1986 | isbn=83-217-2481-7 | id=(1. A-M), {{isbn|83-217-2745-X}} (2. N-Z) }}</ref> He took permanent residence in Moscow, and was given a post at Moscow's Institute for Mathematics<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/> and a post of trainer of the USSR national team.<ref>{{cite book | author=Weinstein, Boris Samoilovich | title='''Myslitel''' (''Thinker'') | publisher=Fizkultura i sport | year=1981 | pages=104 (Russian edition) | accessdate=2009-02-18 }}</ref> Lasker returned to competitive chess to make some money, finishing fifth in [[Zürich 1934 chess tournament|Zürich 1934]] and third in [[Moscow 1935 chess tournament|Moscow 1935]] (undefeated, ½ point behind [[Mikhail Botvinnik]] and [[Salo Flohr]]; ahead of Capablanca, [[Rudolf Spielmann]] and several Soviet masters), sixth in Moscow 1936 and seventh equal in [[Nottingham]] 1936.<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1930Al1939"/> His performance in Moscow 1935 at age 66 was hailed as "a biological miracle."<ref>{{cite book | author=Reuben Fine | title=The World's Great Chess Games | publisher=Dover | year=1976 | page=51 | isbn=0-486-24512-8 }}</ref>
[[Joseph Stalin]]'s [[Great Purge]] started at about the same time the Laskers arrived in the USSR.
===Return to the United States and death=== In August 1937, Martha and Emanuel Lasker decided to leave the Soviet Union, and they moved, via the Netherlands, to the United States (first Chicago, next New York) in October 1937.<ref>{{cite book | author=Weinstein, Boris Samoilovich | title='''Myslitel''' (''Thinker'') | publisher=Fizkultura i sport | year=1981 | pages=105 (Russian edition) | accessdate=2009-02-18 }}</ref> The next year Emanuel Lasker's patron, Krylenko, was removed from his office and executed. Meanwhile, in the United States Lasker tried to support himself by giving chess and bridge lectures and exhibitions, as he was now too old for serious competition.<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/><ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/> In 1940 he published his last book, ''The Community of the Future'', in which he proposed solutions for serious political problems, including [[anti-Semitism]] and unemployment.<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/>
Lasker died of a [[kidney]] infection in New York on January 11, 1941, at the age of 72, as a charity patient at the [[Mount Sinai Hospital, New York|Mount Sinai Hospital]].<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/> He was buried at historic Beth Olom Cemetery, Queens, New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/631|title=Dr Emanuel Lasker (1868–1941) – Find A Grave...|website=Findagrave.com|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> His wife Martha and his sister, Mrs. Lotta Hirschberg, survived him.<ref>{{cite web | title=5076. Lasker's last words | author=Winter, Edward | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/winter36.html#5076._Laskers_last_words_C.N._4705 | publisher=ChessHistory | accessdate=2008-12-28 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Landsberger, K. | title=The Steinitz Papers: Letters and Documents of the First World Chess Champion | publisher=McFarland | year=2002 | isbn= 0-7864-1193-7 | page=295 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=NltT4BinugsC&pg=PA295&dq=lasker+capablanca+1921 | accessdate=2008-12-28 }}</ref>
== Assessment ==
=== Playing strength and style === Lasker was considered to have a "psychological" method of play in which he considered the subjective qualities of his opponent, in addition to the objective requirements of his position on the board. [[Richard Réti]] published a lengthy analysis of Lasker's play in which he concluded that Lasker deliberately played inferior moves that he knew would make his opponent uncomfortable.<ref>Réti wrote, "In analyzing Lasker's tournament games, I was struck by his lasting and at first seemingly incredible good luck. ... There is no denying the fact that over and over again Lasker's exposition is poor, that he is in a losing position hundreds of times and, nevertheless, wins in the end."{{cite book | author=Réti, Richard | title=Masters of the Chessboard | publisher=Dover Publications | year=1976 | page=132 | isbn=0-486-23384-7 }} Réti considered, but rejected as too improbable, the "hypothesis of lasting luck", finally concluding that the only explanation for Lasker's repeated success from bad positions is that he "often plays badly on purpose". ''Id.'' Réti concluded that Lasker studied his opponents' strong and weak points, and that, "He is not so much interested in making the objectively best moves as he is in making those most disagreeable to his opponent; he turns the game in a direction not suitable to the style of his opponent and on this unaccustomed road leads him to the abyss, often by means of intentionally bad moves, as I have previously described." ''Id.'' at 133.</ref> [[William Pollock (chess player)|W. H. K. Pollock]] commented, "It is no easy matter to reply correctly to Lasker's bad moves."<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=9SECAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Pollock+Memories%22&printsec=frontcover | author=Rowland, Mrs. F.F. | title=Pollock Memories: A Collection of Chess Games, Problems, &c., &c. | publisher=Chess Player's Chronicle | year=1899 | page=78 | isbn=978-1-4371-9392-3 }}</ref>
Lasker himself denied the claim that he deliberately played bad moves, and most modern writers agree. According to [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] [[Andrew Soltis]] and [[International Master]] [[John L. Watson]], the features that made his play mysterious to contemporaries now appear regularly in modern play: the g2–g4 "Spike" attack against the [[Sicilian Defence, Dragon Variation|Dragon Sicilian]];{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} [[Sacrifice (chess)|sacrifices]] to gain positional advantage; playing the "practical" move rather than trying to find the best move; counterattacking and complicating the game before a disadvantage became serious.<ref name="SoltisLaskerMatters">{{cite book | title=Why Lasker Matters | author=Soltis, A. | publisher=Batsford | year=2005 | page=5 | isbn=0-7134-8983-9 | url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/jwatsonbkrev80.html }} The URL is a review by [[John L. Watson]]. Another review, with examples, is at {{cite web | url=http://www.chesscafe.com/text/review538.pdf | accessdate=2009-01-01 | title=Analyzing an Enigma | publisher=ChessCafe | author=Taylor Kingston }}</ref><ref>"Lasker's greatest skill in defense was his ability to render a normal (inferior) position chaotic": {{cite book | author=Crouch, C. | title=How to Defend in Chess | publisher=Everyman | year=2000 | isbn=1-85744-250-4 }}; review including this quotation at {{cite web | title=How to Defend in Chess: review | author=Watson, J. | url=http://www.jeremysilman.com/book_reviews_jw/jw_ht_defend_chess.html | publisher=JeremySilman | accessdate=2008-11-19 }}</ref> Former World Champion [[Vladimir Kramnik]] said, "He realized that different types of advantage could be interchangeable: tactical edge could be converted into strategic advantage and vice versa", which mystified contemporaries who were just becoming used to the theories of Steinitz as codified by [[Siegbert Tarrasch]].<ref name="KramnikSteinitzToKasparov"/>
[[Max Euwe]] opined that the real reason behind Lasker's success was his "exceptional defensive technique" and that "almost all there is to say about defensive chess can be demonstrated by examples from the games of Steinitz and Lasker", with the former exemplifying passive defence and the latter an active defence.<ref>{{cite book | author=[[Max Euwe]] and Hans Kramer | title=The Middlegame | publisher=Hays Publishing | year=1994 | pages=93, 101 }}</ref>
The famous win against [[José Raúl Capablanca]] at [[St. Petersburg 1914 chess tournament|St. Petersburg in 1914]], which Lasker needed in order to retain any chance of catching up with Capablanca, is sometimes offered as evidence of his "psychological" approach. [[Reuben Fine]] describes Lasker's choice of opening, the [[Ruy Lopez, Exchange Variation|Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez]], as "innocuous but psychologically potent".<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/> However, an analysis of Lasker's use of this variation throughout his career concludes that he had excellent results with it as White against top-class opponents, and sometimes used it in "must-win" situations.<ref name="WrinnLaskerRuyExchangeVariation">As White in [[Ruy Lopez, Exchange Variation|Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez]] Lasker scored ten wins, three draws and just one loss, to Steinitz in 1894. Lasker also won the three recorded games in which he played the variation as Black; one was against [[Alexander Alekhine|Alekhine]], in the 1914 St. Petersburg Tournament, the day before Lasker beat Capablanca.{{cite web | url=http://www.chesscafe.com/text/skittles230.pdf | title=Lasker and the Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez - Part 1 | author=Wrinn, Steve | accessdate=2008-06-09 | publisher=ChessCafe | format=PDF }} and {{cite web | url=http://www.chesscafe.com/text/skittles232.pdf | title=Lasker and the Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez – Part 2 | author=Wrinn, Steve | accessdate=2008-06-09 | publisher=ChessCafe | format=PDF }}</ref> [[Luděk Pachman]] writes that Lasker's choice presented his opponent with a [[dilemma]]: with only a ½ point lead, Capablanca would have wanted to play safe; but the Exchange Variation's [[pawn structure]] gives White an [[Chess endgame|endgame]] advantage, and Black must use his {{chessgloss|bishop pair}} aggressively in the [[middlegame]] to nullify this.<ref name="Pachman1987StPetersburg1914">{{cite book|last=Pachman|first=L.|title=Decisive Games in Chess History|publisher=Courier Dover|year=1987|pages=64–68|chapter=St Petersburg 1914: Drawing Variation - The Way to Victory|isbn=0-486-25323-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jlgJTCyonAgC&pg=PA1&dq=capablanca|accessdate=2009-06-04}}</ref> In Kramnik's opinion, Lasker's play in this game demonstrated deep positional understanding, rather than psychology.<ref name="KramnikSteinitzToKasparov">{{cite web |url = http://www.kramnik.com/eng/interviews/getinterview.aspx?id=61 |accessdate = 2009-01-02 |title = Kramnik Interview: From Steinitz to Kasparov |author = [[Vladimir Kramnik]] |publisher = Kramnik.com |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080512052013/http://www.kramnik.com/eng/interviews/getinterview.aspx?id=61 |archive-date = 2008-05-12 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
Fine reckoned Lasker paid little attention to the openings,<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/> but Capablanca thought Lasker knew the openings very well but disagreed with a lot of contemporary opening analysis. In fact before the 1894 world title match, Lasker studied the openings thoroughly, especially Steinitz's favorite lines. He played primarily e4 openings, particularly the [[Ruy Lopez]]. He opened with 1.d4 relatively rarely, although his d4 games had a higher winning percentage than his e4 ones. With the Black pieces, he mainly answered 1.e4 with the [[French Defense]] and 1.d4 with the [[Queen's Gambit]]. Lasker also used the [[Sicilian Defense]] fairly often. In Capablanca's opinion, no player surpassed Lasker in the ability to assess a position quickly and accurately, in terms of who had the better prospects of winning and what strategy each side should adopt.<ref name="HavanurReviewWhyLaskerMatters">{{cite web | url=http://www.chessville.com/reviews/WhyLaskerMatters2.htm | title=Why Lasker Matters – review by Nagesh Havanur | author=Nagesh Havanur | publisher=ChessVille | accessdate=2008-11-21 }}</ref> Capablanca also wrote that Lasker was so adaptable that he played in no definite style, and that he was both a tenacious defender and a very efficient finisher of his own attacks.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Capablanca, José Raúl | title=The Ideal Style of the Masters | newspaper=Mundial | date=May 1927 | pages=1–4 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/capablanca3.html | accessdate=2009-01-02 | authorlink=José Raúl Capablanca }}</ref>
Lasker followed [[Wilhelm Steinitz|Steinitz]]'s principles, and both demonstrated a completely different chess paradigm than the “romantic” mentality before them. Thanks to Steinitz and Lasker, positional players gradually became common ([[Siegbert Tarrasch|Tarrasch]], [[Carl Schlechter|Schlechter]], and [[Akiba Rubinstein|Rubinstein]] stand out.) But, while Steinitz created a new school of chess thought, Lasker’s talents were far harder for the masses to grasp; hence there was no Lasker school.<ref>{{cite book | author=Garry Kasparov | title=My Great Predecessors - Part I | publisher=Everyman Chess | year=2003 | pages=187–222 | isbn=1857443306 }}</ref>
In addition to his enormous chess skill, Lasker was said to have an excellent competitive temperament: his rival [[Siegbert Tarrasch]] once said, "Lasker occasionally loses a game, but he never loses his head."<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/> Lasker enjoyed the need to adapt to varying styles and to the shifting fortunes of tournaments.<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/> Although very strong in matches, he was even stronger in tournaments. For over 20 years, he always finished ahead of the younger Capablanca: at St. Petersburg 1914, New York 1924, Moscow 1925, and Moscow 1935.<ref>{{cite book | author=Harry Golombek | title=Capablanca's 100 Best Games of Chess | publisher=David McKay | year=1978 | pages=37, 88, 116, 222 | isbn=0-679-14044-1 }}</ref> Only in 1936 (15 years after their match), when Lasker was 67, did Capablanca finish ahead of him.<ref>{{cite book | author=Reuben Fine | title=The World's Great Chess Games | publisher=Dover | year=1976 | page=50 | isbn=0-486-24512-8 }}</ref>
In 1964, ''Chessworld'' magazine published an article in which future World Champion [[Bobby Fischer]] listed the ten greatest players in history.<ref>Bobby Fischer, "The Ten Greatest Masters in History", ''Chessworld'', Vol. 1, No. 1 (January–February 1964), pp. 56-61.</ref> Fischer did not include Lasker in the list, deriding him as a "coffee-house player [who] knew nothing about openings and didn't understand positional chess".<ref>Fischer, "The Ten Greatest Masters in History", p. 59.</ref> In a poll of the world's leading players taken some time after Fischer's list appeared, Tal, Korchnoi, and [[Robert Byrne (chess player)|Robert Byrne]] all said that Lasker was the greatest player ever.<ref>{{cite book | title=Profile of a Prodigy | author=Brady, Frank | publisher=David McKay | year=1973 | edition=2nd | page=78 | isbn=0-486-25925-0 }}</ref> Both [[Pal Benko]] and Byrne stated that Fischer later reconsidered and said that Lasker was a great player.<ref name="Benko">{{cite book | title=Pal Benko: My Life, Games and Compositions | author1=Benko, Pal | author2=Silman, Jeremy | publisher=Siles Press | year=2003 | page=429 | isbn=1-890085-08-1 }}</ref><ref>Brady 1973, p. 79.</ref>
Statistical ranking systems place Lasker high among the greatest players of all time. The book ''Warriors of the Mind'' places him sixth, behind [[Garry Kasparov]], [[Anatoly Karpov]], Fischer, [[Mikhail Botvinnik]] and Capablanca.<ref name="WarriorsOfTheMind">{{Cite book | title=Warriors of the Mind | last1=Keene | first1=Raymond | author1-link=Raymond Keene | last2=Divinsky | first2=Nathan | author2-link=Nathan Divinsky | year=1989 | publisher=Hardinge Simpole | location=Brighton, UK | isbn=0-9513757-2-5 }} See the summary list at {{cite web |url=http://chess.eusa.ed.ac.uk/Chess/Trivia/AlltimeList.html |accessdate=2008-11-21 |publisher=Edinburgh University Chess Club |title=All Time Rankings |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126000035/http://chess.eusa.ed.ac.uk/Chess/Trivia/AlltimeList.html |archivedate=2009-11-26 |df= }}</ref> In his 1978 book ''The Rating of Chessplayers, Past and Present'', [[Arpad Elo]] gave retrospective ratings to players based on their performance over the best five-year span of their career. He concluded that Lasker was the joint second strongest player of those surveyed (tied with Botvinnik and behind Capablanca).<ref>{{cite book | title=The Rating of Chessplayers, Past and Present | author=Elo, A. | year=1978 | publisher=Arco | isbn=0-668-04721-6 | url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=1160 | authorlink=Arpad Elo }} The URL provides greater detail, covering 47 players whom Elo rated, and notes that [[Bobby Fischer]] and [[Anatoly Karpov]] would have topped the list if the January 1, 1978, [[FIDE]] ratings had been included (FIDE ratings use Elo's system).</ref> The most up-to-date system, [[Chessmetrics]], is rather sensitive to the length of the periods being compared, and ranks Lasker between fifth and second strongest of all time for peak periods ranging in length from one to twenty years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PeakList.asp?Params=199510SSSSS1S000000000000111000000000000010100 |title=Peak Average Ratings: 1 year peak range |publisher=Chessmetrics |author=[[Jeff Sonas]] |accessdate=2008-06-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309155451/http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PeakList.asp?Params=199510SSSSS1S000000000000111000000000000010100 |archivedate=2012-03-09 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PeakList.asp?Params=199510SSSSS5S000000000000111000000000000010100 |title=Peak Average Ratings: 5 year peak range |publisher=Chessmetrics |author=[[Jeff Sonas]] |url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PeakList.asp?Params=199510SSSSSFS000000000000111000000000000010100 |title=Peak Average Ratings: 15 year peak range |publisher=Chessmetrics |author=[[Jeff Sonas]]
